summary: This document is a compilation of media articles and social media posts from July 2019 to March 2020 focusing on Ghislaine Maxwell following Jeffrey Epstein's death. It shows her becoming a primary media target, facing public accusations, death threats, and a bounty offer, and includes her lawsuit against Epstein's estate citing death threats and legal fees.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.role: Accused enabler and associate of Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the media analysis; described as Epstein's 'Lady of the House,' a long-term associate, an alleged enabler in sex trafficking, and the target of public threats and a bounty. She sues Epstein's estate citing death threats and legal fees.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as the central figure in the case, now deceased. Described as having been entangled with Ghislaine Maxwell and for whom Maxwell allegedly recruited victims.

connections.description: Described as long entangled, with Maxwell portrayed as Epstein's 'Lady of the House' and an alleged enabler/recruiter in his activities.

events.title: NY Times profiles Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: The New York Times publishes an article profiling Ghislaine Maxwell as 'The Lady of the House' who was long entangled with Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Media outlets accuse Maxwell of recruiting
events.description: The New York Post and Washington Post publish articles accusing Ghislaine Maxwell of being part of Epstein's 'gang of accused slave recruiters' and stating accusers will go after his alleged enablers.

events.title: Bounty offered for information on Maxwell
events.description: The Sun newspaper offers a £10,000 reward for information on Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Maxwell sues Epstein's estate
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell sues Jeffrey Epstein's estate, citing death threats and extensive legal fees.

keyFacts: Following Jeffrey Epstein's death in July 2019, Ghislaine Maxwell became the primary focus of media scrutiny and public anger, labeled as 'Person #1' in the case.
Multiple media outlets in 2019 explicitly accused Maxwell of being a key recruiter or enabler in Epstein's alleged sex trafficking operation.
Maxwell faced severe and violent death threats on social media, with users calling for her to be killed or imprisoned.
A £10,000 bounty was offered by The Sun newspaper in November 2019 for information leading to Ghislaine Maxwell.
In March 2020, Ghislaine Maxwell sued Jeffrey Epstein's estate, citing the death threats against her and her extensive legal fees as reasons.
